text.lat: 169.— Athenae diu a tyrranis oppressae erant. His tandem coactis ut exsulatum abirent, auctae sunt Athenarum opes: civitasque florentissima facta est. Apparet autem, non hoc solum exemplo, sed ubique, quam praeclara res sit iuris aequalitas. Nam et Athenienses, quamdiu sub tyrannis erant, nullis ex finitimis populis bello fuerunt superiores; tyrannis autem liberati, longe primi facti sunt. Quae res declarat, quoad a tyrannis essent oppressi, illos minus fortiter rem gessisse, quippe pro domino non pro se: postquam vero in libertatem sunt restituti, unusquisque pro se ipse studiose dabat operam ut recte rem gereret.
text.eng: 169.—Athens had long been oppressed by tyrants. When they were finally compelled to go into exile, the power of Athens increased: the city became very flourishing. It appears, however, not only from this example, but everywhere, how splendid a thing is the equality of rights. For the Athenians, as long as they were under tyrants, were superior to no neighboring peoples in war; but once freed from the tyrants, they became by far the first. This fact shows that, so long as they were oppressed by tyrants, they managed affairs less bravely, indeed for their master, not for themselves: but after they were restored to liberty, each diligently took care for himself to manage affairs rightly.
